title: When will Fitch, Moody's, or S&P, next downgrade China's long term local or foreign currency issuer ratings?
preds: Well screwed this one up, hoping to get a few days to improve my percentages.
There have been announcements to reduce the debt levels of SOEs, which would reduce the risks of a downgrade in the near future.
Seems that debt is a concern.

China has prioritized exchange rate stability over liberalization.  The policy effect of this approach I s the decreased risk in the near term of a fall in the value of the renminbi relative to USD.  Over a longer term we can expect a moderate depreciation of the currency but it has largely limited its risk factors on both currency and sovereign rating, currently at ... and indicates no downgrade in both short and long term.
If S&P don't make a move within the next 9/10 months, China could have made significant progress on it's remediation of local balance sheets.

In my mind, this question largely reads "when will S&P lower China's rating?" as S&P are one step above Moody's and Fitch's. S&P have said they're probably going to follow the regular review schedule but have not said when the next review for China will be. The previous three have been: Jul 31 2008, Dec 16 2010 and Mar 31 2016 (https://tradingeconomics.com/china/rating) . Admittedly this does not give a whole lot of information. Earlier annual updates were given so I suppose those are not out of the question either. In fact, one could argue that the reason S&P are following their regular schedule IS that they have an update schedule for this year already. In the current state, I think it is quite possible that S&P will reduce the rating whenever they have the next update scheduled. Whether that update is schedule later, however, might always change things as China might be doing better by then. Given the recent update schedule I'd say the update for 2017 is possible but unlikely but for 2018 it is more likely (it would be odd to issue a statement basically saying "we see no reason to review China before 2019"). If I start with the likeliness for an update in 2017, I'd say the chances are about 20-50% I will take into account that S&P might change their mind and speed things up.
For 2018 the update is likely and currently it seems it COULD indeed bring a downgrade as well. I'll give this a 40%-70% chance
Not before 1 January 2019 remains. I think here I'm effectively evaluating whether or not S&P had their scheduled meeting and decided not to downgrade the rating for China. I give that a 20% chance. Therefore final numbers:
25% Before January 2018
25% Between 1 Jan and 30 Jun
30% Between 1 Jul and 31 Dec
20% Not before 2019
May 2018,  the market will destabilize due to fighting.
the downgrade was a large one and it is hard to see it going lower in the short terms given that it is putatively correct right now.
Chin's growth will slow as it becomes more mature but this will be a slow change.
China's growth cannot maintain its recent level so some downgrading of economic expectations is to be expected and it only takes one of the three rating agencies to downgrade.
China has a stability that the US does not have right now.

The long term issues facing China that caused Moody's to downgrade the country haven't changed and won't change anytime soon. As well, S&P has had a negative outlook for China since March of 2016 while Fitch has recently reaffirmed its rating. I think Fitch and Moody's will downgrade their outlook before a credit downgrade so it all comes down to S&P and they have stated (see link) that a downgrade is a real possibility but that they are not in a hurry. http://www.reuters.com/article/china-russia-ratings-sp-idUSL9N1CD01I

Moodys and Fitch have China at a "stable" outlook, while S&P have "neg" citing decreasing growth. The above expectations growth figures for Q2 might alleviate that concern in the short-term. The under-regulated shadow banking sector and buildup of leverage may sway to the downside in the longer run. S&P's own analysis is conveniently ambiguous on their current view... https://www.capitaliq.com/CIQDotNet/CreditResearch/RenderArticle.aspx?articleId=1879934&SctArtId=431050&from=CM&nsl_code=LIME&sourceObjectId=10137084&sourceRevId=3&fee_ind=N&exp_date=20270712-00:44:49 Implied probability of default derived from CDS spreads, assuming a recovery rate of 0.40, is 0.28 % in 1 year, and 0.41 % in 2 years, giving a baseline for the market outlook on China credit-worthiness.
http://www.dbresearch.com/PROD/DBR_INTERNET_EN-PROD/PROD0000000000183612.pdf
Local downgrades first.  The provinces are where the problems lay.

In the last 4 times that S&P changed outlook on China (without changing their rating), here is what happened: (1) in 3 occurences, they changed rating within a year, (4) in the  4th occurence, they changed rating 4 years later. The average of these 4 datapoints indicates a downgrade occurence rate of 80% rate per year, following an outlook change.
I have ignored the possibility of a further downgrade from Moody's and Fitch.
Will update with a more precise forecast soon.

If Fitch, Moody's, or S&P downgrade Zhongguo, they can wave goodbye to their current status. Fascinating issue is if they will gamble with death. 1.Fitch Affirms China’s A+ Rating and Says Short-term Growth Prospects Are Favourable
http://fortune.com/2017/07/14/fitch-china-economic-growth/ 2.Moody's is at A1 stable. 
http://countryeconomy.com/ratings/china 3. S & P is the only one with a negative outlook. There is a "real" chance of a downgrade to China's credit rating, S&P Global's top sovereign analyst said on Tuesday
https://www.reuters.com/article/china-russia-ratings-sp-idUSL9N1CD01I

S&P will downgrade China.  "The next question is whether S&P will follow Moody's. S&P has had China on outlook negative since February 2016, indicating there is a potential downgrade brewing. But S&P currently rates China one notch above Moody's and Fitch, so a cut would not break new ground."

China is a master currency manipulator and trying to reace the USD as a reserve currency. They'll uze all the tools they have to avoid another downgrade for as long as they can. The agencies are well aware that a asian market scare woulld affect clients around the globe.
